_exec_summary.SummaryText:
STATIONARY SOURCE DESCRIPTION

The Badlands Gas Plant is owned and operated by Hiland Partners. The facility is a mechanical refrigeration gas processing plant with front end hydrogen sulfide removal (via solid media), amine treating (to remove carbon dioxide), tail end nitrogen removal (via a cold box), and product storage. The facility receives natural gas via high pressure and low pressure gas gathering systems. The inlet streams are commingled within the plant, and the hydrocarbon liquids (propane and BG mix---primarily butane and pentanes) are removed from the gas and sold as products. The products are trucked from the plant and the residue gas (methane) is transported via pipeline to the field compressors as fuel, with the surplus going to sales.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION

The operating personnel of the Badlands Gas Plant are committed to protecting the health and safety of company employees, contractors working at the facility, residents near the plant, and the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested and the emphasis placed on safety by Hiland Partners in the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of this and other facilities. There are both administrative and engineering controls in place at the plant to minimize the risk of an uncontrolled release of a hazardous substance.



This facility is regulated by 29 CFR 1910.119 (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals), 29 CFR 1910.38 (Employee Emergency Plans), 29 CFR 1910.120 (Hazardous Waste and Emergency Response), 40 CFR 112 (Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure Plans), as well as other federal, state and local regulations developed to reduce the risk of release of hazardous chemicals. Strict compliance with these regulations by plant operating personnel ensures the risk of release is kept to a minimum.



Safe work practices are in place to ensure safe operations consistent with industry practice and that meet regulatory requirements.  Sa

fe work practices include site control, lockout/tagout, line breaking, confined space entry, and hot work procedures.



WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

In accordance with the EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR Part 68), the plant's inventory of chemicals was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable or toxic substances were present in quantities above the threshold amount. It was found that certain listed chemicals in the stored quantities of the propane and BG mix (primarily butanes and pentanes), and condensate exceeded the threshold value of 10,000 lb for flamable chemicals. These flammable chemicals are stored in common area and comprise a single covered process. No toxic substances exist at the plant in quantities that exceed the threshold.



The worst-case scenario for this facility would be a vapor cloud explosion of the total quantity of stored flammables (over 200,000 lb). Using procedures in EPA's Risk Management Program for Offsite Consequences Analysis, the estimated distance to an overpressure endpoint of 1 psi from this explosion was found to be 0.6 miles.  The nearest distance to a public receptor (a manned industrial facility) is less than this distance. According to 2000 Census data, there are no residents within this distance.  The proximity the Badlands facility to public receptors necessitates a change of the faciliity from a Program Level 1 to a Program Level 3 of the Risk Management Program.



This type of scenario is very unlikely to occur. All pressure vessels are carefully inspected and pressure tested before they are put into service, and the rigorous mechanical integrity program followed by the plant ensures that all process equipment is properly maintained and inspected on a regular basis. 



ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

An alternative release scenario was performed using the same procedures described above, reduslting in an endpont of 0.5 miles.  Public receptors also lie within this area but no residents.



5-YEAR ACCIDENT

HISTORY

There have been no releases of hazardous substances at the Badlands Gas Plant over the last five years that resulted in offsite effects.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Badlands Gas Plant maintains a written emergency response plan. The plan is reviewed and updated to assure applicability with the plant. The employees are trained for emergency response per OSHA HAZWOPER Standard 1910.120(q). Plant emergency response actions are coordinated with the local emergency response agencies, including the Rhame and Bowman fire departments. Annual emergency response training of the employees and meetings with the local emergency response agencies are conducted to assure communication processes are maintained. In addition, the plant conducts drills that involve the local emergency response agencies.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Plant personnel are continually developing new ways to improve the safety of the facility. Input from operating personnel regarding plant safety is always sought during safety meetings.
